questions.text: A 25 year old male presents with exertional dyspnea and chest pain while playing table tennis. Echocardiography shows systolic anterior movement of mitral valve with LV free wall thickness of 30 mm. He informs you about the sudden death of his elder brother while dancing at a marriage party. Which of the following is the best intervention for management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Implantable cardioverter defibrillator

The diagnosis based on clinical and echo findings is hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. In lieu of significant ventricular hypertrophy of 30 mm thickness and SCD in sibling, implantable cardioverter defibrillator is best intervention in this patient.

Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator indications in HCM

-Unexplained syncope

-Abnormal blood pressure response during exercise

-Significant ventricular hypertrophy (>30mm thickness)

-Family history of SCD

-Multiple episodes of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT)

questions.text: A 55 year old woman presents with acute chest pain and difficulty breathing after learning of the death of her daughter in an air crash . Her ECG shows ST-segment elevation in lead I,aVL, V2-V4. Cardiac biomarkers are elevated. Bed side echocardiography reveals ballooning of the left ventricular apex. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy

Explanation:

In the setting of intense emotional trauma causing catecholamine excess and Echo findings of LV apex ballooning, the diagnosis is Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Option A is the first differential diagnosis of this presentation in case the echo findings were not given. Aortic dissection will cause unequal BP between both arms and coronary artery dissection. Brugada occurs in young males and causes Sudden nocturnal death.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with sharp chest pain, fever, and inspiratory catch on taking deep breath 3 weeks after undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct option: B) Post-cardiac injury syndrome

Explanation:

This patient’s presentation is consistent with postcardiac injury syndrome, often resulting from an autoimmune response to antigens from the injured myocardium following surgery. The resultant autoimmune pericarditis explains chest pain and pleuritis explains the inspiratory catch in breath.

Causes can be

  1. Post-MI (Dressler syndrome)
  2. Post Surgery ( open heart surgery, CABG, Valve replacement)
  3. Post trauma ( pacemaker lead placement , blunt trauma to chest)

Option A has Kussmaul sign, pericardial shock and visible calcification around the heart on CT chest. Option C will cause the heart to burst after transmural MI and causes death. Option D is seen with SLE or vasculitis.

questions.text: A post-mortem study reveals deposits between the pericardial layers with a “bread and butter” appearance. Which of the following is most consistent with this form of pericarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Fibrinous pericarditis

Explanation:

The “bread and butter” appearance is characteristic of fibrinous pericarditis, marked by fibrin and leukocytic exudate on the pericardium.

Bread and butter appearance seen in fibrinous pericarditis

Types of Pericarditis

Fibrinous pericarditis

Often called "bread and butter" pericarditis due to fibrin deposits creating a rough appearance on the pericardium.

Caused by conditions like myocardial infarction, infections, trauma, or systemic diseases.

Purulent pericarditis

Caused by bacterial infections, leading to a pus-filled pericardial sac.

Haemorrhagic pericarditis

Involves blood within the pericardium, often due to trauma, malignancy ( lung cancer) or uremia.

Caseous pericarditis

Rare and typically associated with tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 50 year old alcoholic presents with worsening fatigue, shortness of breath, and leg swelling. The Chest X-ray and Cardiac MRI of the patient are given below. Which of the following statements regarding the treatment of her condition is FALSE?

choices.text: Low dose diuretics should be administered to maintain an euvolemic state.
ACE inhibitors are recommended for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.
Beta-blockers should not be used in patients with chronic heart failure.

questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Beta-blockers should not be used in patients with chronic heart failure.

Explanation:

CXR shows an increased CT ratio. Cardiac MRI shows reduced thickness of all chambers of the heart.. This implies the patient is having alcohol induced dilated cardiomyopathy, causing symptoms of heart failure. Beta blockers reduce mortality in chronic heart failure.

Cardiac resynchronisation therapy is done to ensure both ventricles contract simultaneously and helps in reducing symptoms in DCM.

questions.text: A 50 year old alcoholic presents with shortness of breath and finding shown in the image . Auscultation reveals pan-systolic murmur. Which of the following findings is most consistent with the diagnosis of this patient?

choices.text: Increased dynamic LV outflow tract obstruction
Point of maximum impulse displaced medially

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Increased Left ventricular diastolic dimension

Explanation:

 The patient is having alcohol induced dilated cardiomyopathy. LV malfunction is causing pulmonary edema, and RV malfunction is causing pitting edema shown in the image. Option A and C are seen in HCM. Displacement of the apex beat is seen in multiple conditions and hence ruled out. DCM will cause displaced hypokinetic apex with dilated, thinned-out cardiac chambers with functional Mitral regurgitation and tricuspid regurgitation, which explains the pansystolic murmur heard in this case.

questions.text: A 55 year old male presents to the emergency department with fatigue, shortness of breath, and swollen legs. CXR is shown below. Echocardiography shows global hypokinesia with reduced thickness of cardiac chambers. Which of the following is NOT a recognised cause of this patient’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Scleroderma

Explanation:

CXR shows an increased CT ratio. The echo shows global hypokinesia with thinned-out cardiac chambers, indicating dilated cardiomyopathy. Scleroderma causes restrictive cardiomyopathy.

Must know causes of Dilated Cardiomyopathy

Infective

  • Viral (coxsackievirus, adenovirus, HIV)
  • Parasitic (Chagas’ disease, trypanosomiasis, toxoplasmosis) (Option B ruled out)
  • Bacterial (diphtheria)
  • Spirochetal (Lyme disease)
  • Rickettsial (Q fever)

Noninfective

  • Granulomatous inflammatory disease
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Giant cell myocarditis
  • Eosinophilic myocarditis
  • Polymyositis, dermatomyositis
  • Collagen vascular disease

Toxic

  • Alcohol
  • Catecholamines (amphetamines, cocaine)
  • Chemotherapeutic agents (anthracyclines, trastuzumab)
  • Other therapeutic agents (hydroxychloroquine, chloroquine)
  • Drugs of misuse (emetine, anabolic steroids)
  • Heavy metals (lead, mercury)

Metabolic

  • Nutritional deficiencies (thiamine, selenium, carnitine)
  • Endocrinopathy (thyroid disease, pheochromocytoma, diabetes, obesity, hemochromatosis)
  • Dystrophin-related dystrophy (Duchenne’s, Becker’s)
  • Mitochondrial myopathies (e.g., Kearns-Sayre syndrome)

questions.text: All of the following are correct about restrictive cardiomyopathy except?

choices.text: Echo shows dilated atria with normal size ventricles and increased LV and RV end diastolic pressures
Cardiac MRI shows starry sky appearance due to amyloidosis
Absent y descent and steep x descent
Endomyocardial biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing cardiac amyloidosis.

questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Absent y descent and steep x descent

Explanation:

Absent y descent and steep x descent is seen in cardiac tamponade. RCM will have steep y descent with blunted/ normal x descent due to atrial wall fibrosis.

RCM has fibrosis in the wall of the ventricles that causes the atria to dilate after having to work against resistance.

Cardiac MRI shows a starry sky pattern in amyloidosis, which is overall the most common cause of this rarest type of cardiomyopathy.

The gold standard test to demonstrate fibrosis is endomyocardial biopsy, which is now being replaced by Cardiac MRI since it is non-invasive and has better sensitivity.

 

Echocardiography showing enlarged atria and speckled appearance of ventricles.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with ascites, shortness of breath, and bilateral ankle edema. Kussmaul's sign is noted. An echocardiogram shows normal systolic function but diastolic dysfunction with a speckled pattern in the ventricular wall. The chest X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements is correct about the diagnosis of this patient?

choices.text: Atrial fibrillation is rare in these patients.
Endomyocardial Fibroelastosis is the leading cause

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Elevated Jugular venous pressure with rapid y descent.

Explanation:

The echocardiogram showing normal systolic function with evidence of diastolic dysfunction and speckled appearance of ventricles implies RCM. That explains pedal edema and pulmonary edema. Atria are enlarged in RCM, ruling out option A. CXR shows a straight left heart border due to atrial enlargement

RCM shows Prominent y descent: Due to elevated atrial pressures, there is rapid early ventricular filling in the diastole, creating a pronounced y descent on atrial pressure curves.

RCM shows blunted x descent: Poor atrial relaxation and limited annular descent toward the apex result in a reduced x descent, as the atrium does not effectively empty or relax

Atrial fibrillation is very common (Option C ruled out); ventricular arrhythmias are rare.

Kussmaul's sign is absent in cardiac tamponade and is seen in RCM

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with worsening fatigue, shortness of breath, and ankle swelling. His medical history includes joint pain, elevated liver enzymes, hyperpigmentation, and diabetes. He has recently been diagnosed with a metabolic disorder. An echocardiogram reveals elevated filling pressures and bilateral atrial enlargement. Which of the following best explains the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Increased contractility due to myocardial hypertrophy
Impaired diastolic filling due to stiffened ventricular walls
Dilated ventricular chambers leading to heart failure
Obstruction of blood flow through the left ventricle

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Impaired diastolic filling due to stiffened ventricular walls

Explanation:

A combination of diabetes, liver damage, joint involvement and hyperpigmentation of skin points to aetiology as Hemochromatosis-induced Restrictive cardiomyopathy. It will cause impaired contractility of stiff ventricles.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female marathon runner collapses and is found unresponsive during a race. Despite attempts at resuscitation, she is pronounced dead in the ER. Her family reports that she had previously experienced episodes of dizziness and palpitations during training. You re-evaluate her ECG done at time of admission which shows epsilon waves. Which of the following conditions is most likely to contribute to sudden cardiac death in this young athlete?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Arrhythmogenic RV dysplasia

Explanation:

The keyword is epsilon wave in ECG that indicates a diagnosis of Arrhythmogenic RV dysplasia (ARVD). Commotio cordis occurs due to blunt trauma to the chest at the peak of the T wave that can trigger Ventricular fibrillation.  ASCVD is unlikely at a young age. HCM will show features of LV hypertrophy on ECG.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is not contraindicated in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Verapamil

Explanation:

Option A and C reduce preload and reduce inflow to the right ventricle. Less inflow to RV implies less inflow to the left ventricle, which is already small in size in HCM. This causes BP to fall

Verapamil does not affect preload. It can be used in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy when beta blockers are contraindicated or not tolerated. It will act on the AV node, reduce heart rate and reduce oxygen consumption of this enlarged heart.

Digoxin will increase oxygen consumption and worsen pre-existing subendocardial ischemia that is present in these patients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with sharp chest pain worsened by lying down and relieved by sitting up. He had a recent viral illness. A friction rub is heard on cardiac auscultation, and the ECG shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Acute pericarditis

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and ECG findings of diffuse ST-segment elevation with PR-segment depression point to acute pericarditis. Auscultation shows pericardial friction rub, and relief of chest pain on sitting up adds to the ECG diagnosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with exertional chest pain and occasional fainting spells. His family history includes a relative who experienced sudden cardiac death. An echocardiogram reveals asymmetric septal hypertrophy. Which of the following is not a characteristic investigatory finding in this condition?

choices.text: Deep, narrow Q waves in the lateral leads
Left ventricle free wall thickness >10 mm

questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Left ventricle free wall thickness >10 mm

Explanation:

The clinical scenario suggests hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) due to the athlete's exertional syncope and family history of sudden cardiac death, alongside echocardiographic findings of asymmetric septal hypertrophy, which are characteristic of HOCM.

However, left ventricle free wall thickness >10 mm is incorrect as HOCM is characterized by left ventricle thickness >15 mm (typically >30 mm in severe cases)

The Brockenbrough–Morrow sign is a paradoxical fall in aortic pulse pressure after a PVC, seen in HOCM, due to worsening dynamic LVOT obstruction.

ECG will show increased voltage in precordial leads due to hypertrophy of LV .

 

ECG features of HOCM

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to the ED after experiencing syncope while playing basketball. He has a palpable double impulse at the apex, and an ECG shows signs of left ventricular hypertrophy. An echocardiogram reveals asymmetric septal thickening with left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Which of the following examination findings would NOT be expected in this patient?

choices.text: Palpable double impulse at the apex
Late-peaking ejection systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border
Pulsus bisferiens on peripheral pulse examination
Prominent y descent in jugular venous pressure (JVP)

questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Prominent y descent in jugular venous pressure (JVP)

Explanation:

The patient's symptoms of syncope during exertion, left ventricular hypertrophy, and asymmetric septal thickening with outflow tract obstruction strongly suggest hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), specifically hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM). Prominent y descent in jugular venous pressure (JVP) is more typical of constrictive pericarditis rather than HOCM.

 

 

Auscultatory Findings in Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM):

Auscultatory Feature

Description

Clinical Relevance

Ejection Systolic Murmur(Option B ruled out)

Late-onset crescendo-decrescendo murmur.

Caused by turbulent blood flow through the obstructed LVOT; best heard at the left sternal border or apex.

Dynamic Changes with Maneuvers

Increased Intensity: Occurs with decreased preload (e.g., Valsalva manoeuvre, amyl nitrite).

Indicates worsening obstruction.

Decreased Intensity: Occurs with increased afterload (e.g., handgrip, inspiration).

Suggests improvement in outflow tract obstruction.

questions.text: A 30-year-old competitive athlete presents with recurrent syncope and exertional chest pain. Examination shows a jerky, forceful pulse. and a mid-systolic murmur at the heart's base. Echocardiography shows asymmetric septal hypertrophy, systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve,. What is the most likely mechanism for his symptoms?

choices.text: Diastolic heart failure due to a dilated left ventricle

questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction

Explanation:

Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction is the hallmark of HOCM caused by asymmetric septal hypertrophy, leading to dynamic obstruction during systole, which explains his effort-related symptoms and murmur.

The young athlete’s symptoms, combined with asymmetric septal hypertrophy, strongly suggest hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy.

The mid-systolic murmur indicates obstruction to blood flow from the left ventricle during systole, which aligns with the presentation of HOCM.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with signs of peripheral oedema and ascites. A chest X-ray reveals the following, and echocardiography confirms a thickened pericardium. Which of the following is not correct regarding his likely condition?

choices.text: Commonly caused by tuberculosis in endemic regions
CT scan can assist in visualizing pericardial calcification

questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Diastolic collapse of the ventricles

Explanation:

The patient’s presentation with peripheral oedema, ascites, elevated JVP, pericardial calcification visible on chest X-ray, and a thickened pericardium on echocardiography is suggestive of constrictive pericarditis. This condition is associated with diastolic dysfunction and signs of right-sided heart failure due to a rigid pericardium restricting heart filling.

Diastolic collapse of the ventricles is seen in cardiac tamponade and not constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with fatigue, abdominal swelling, and peripheral oedema. On examination, he has elevated jugular venous pressure, hepatomegaly, and a loud diastolic sound. There is also a rise in JVP during inspiration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Constrictive pericarditis

Explanation:

The patient has classic features like elevated JVP with a rapid y descent, pericardial knock(loud 3rd heart sound), Kussmaul’s sign (Paradoxical rise in JVP during inspiration), hepatomegaly, and peripheral oedema, all suggestive of constriction around the heart.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed car accident. His vitals are heart rate of 120 bpm, blood pressure of 80/50 mmHg, and he is pale with cold, clammy skin. He has a deep laceration on his lower thigh and is actively bleeding. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management step?

choices.text: Apply a tourniquet to the thigh

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Apply a tourniquet to the thigh

Explanation:

 

In exsanguinating limb haemorrhage, the tourniquet is the priority intervention, even before IV fluids.

questions.text:
A 60 year old woman with stage 4 carcinoma breast presents to the ED with severe shortness of breath. On examination, she is hypotensive with a blood pressure of 80/60 mmHg, has distended neck veins with a jugular venous pressure of 12 cm H₂O, and her heart sounds are muffled. An echocardiogram shows the following:



What is the most appropriate immediate and definitive treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Pericardiocentesis

Explanation:

This patient's presentation—severe hypotension, distended neck veins, muffled heart sounds, and echocardiographic evidence of right ventricular collapse—suggests cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: Which of the following is a classic finding in cardiac tamponade?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Pulsus paradoxus

Explanation:

Pulsus paradoxus is a hallmark finding in cardiac tamponade, characterized by a significant drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration (greater than 10 mm Hg). It occurs due to the impaired filling of the heart chambers caused by pericardial fluid compression, limiting cardiac output during inspiration. This phenomenon is commonly observed in cardiac tamponade and serves as a key diagnostic feature in such cases.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of shortness of breath, fatigue, and mild chest discomfort. On examination, his blood pressure is low, and his heart sounds are faint on auscultation. The physician orders an echocardiogram, which shows the following



Based on these findings, which of the following ECG pattern would you most likely expect to see?
questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms, vitals and echocardiographic findings which reveal a large fluid collection around the heart, with evidence of impaired filling of the right-sided chambers are suggestive of cardiac tamponade, likely due to a large pericardial effusion.

  • Electrical alternans is a classic ECG finding in pericardial effusion, particularly when it leads to cardiac tamponade.
  • It manifests as beat-to-beat variations in the amplitude of the QRS complexes, reflecting the heart's movement within the fluid-filled pericardial space.
  • This finding is indicative of significant fluid accumulation and increased intrapericardial pressure, which impedes the heart's ability to fill properly during diastole.

ECG showing Electrical alternans

Red arrows showing variations in the amplitude of QRS complexes

Chest X-ray showing waterbottle configuration in Pericardial effusion 

 

High-voltage QRS complexes (Option A): High-voltage QRS complexes suggest an increased electrical activity due to conditions like left ventricular hypertrophy or other myocardial adaptations. However, in pericardial effusion, there are low-voltage QRS complexes.

 

ST-segment elevation in all leads (Option B): This finding is more characteristic of acute pericarditis, where widespread ST-segment elevations occur due to inflammation of the pericardial sac. In pericardial effusion or tamponade, ST-segment changes are not the defining features.

 

Prolonged PR interval (Option C): A prolonged PR interval typically indicates delayed conduction through the atrioventricular node. Although PR segment depression can occur in acute pericarditis, a prolonged PR interval is not a hallmark of pericardial effusion or tamponade.

questions.text: A 60 y/o male with acute pericarditis who has not responded to NSAIDs and colchicine is now experiencing frequent recurrences. He does not tolerate glucocorticoids well. What additional treatment can be considered?

choices.text: Begin a higher dose of colchicine

questions.solution:
In cases where NSAIDs, colchicine, and glucocorticoids have failed, immunosuppressive therapy such as azathioprine can be considered. Azathioprine is used for patients with recurrent, refractory pericarditis who have multiple episodes lasting for extended periods.

 

Acute Pericarditis

Investigations

Treatment
  • Echocardiography:
    • The primary tool for diagnosing pericardial fluid.
    • Significant pericardial effusion can be identified if fluid exceeds 1 cm.
  • CT & MRI:
    • Detect loculated effusions, masses, or inflammation (MRI)
    • Used to confirm pericardial effusion or thickening.
    • MRI also assesses fibrosis and constrictive pericarditis.

Conservative Management:

Rest and anti-inflammatory drugs for idiopathic pericarditis.

  • Aspirin/NSAIDs:
    • Doses: Aspirin (2-4 g/day) or ibuprofen/indomethacin with gastric protection.
    • Continue for 1-2 weeks, and taper over time.
  • Colchicine:
    • Dose: 0.5 mg daily (<70 kg) or twice daily (>70 kg) for 3 months.
    • Reduces recurrence risk but may cause diarrhoea.
  • Glucocorticoids:
    • Only for NSAID/colchicine-resistant cases, short-term use (2-4 days), then tapered.
    • Prolonged use raises the recurrence risk.
  • Immunosuppressants: Azathioprine or anakinra in cases of frequent recurrence is unresponsive to other treatments.
  • Avoid Anticoagulants: Risk of bleeding into the pericardial cavity, leading to tamponade.

Surgical: Pericardial stripping for rare, severe cases with recurrent effusion.

 

Increase the dose of NSAIDs (Option A): NSAIDs are effective for inflammation control in the short term, but increasing the dosage does not provide additional benefit once recurrences occur.

 

Begin a higher dose of colchicine (Option C): Increasing the dose beyond the recommended levels is not advisable, as colchicine has a narrow therapeutic window. Higher doses increase the risk of gastrointestinal side effects, such as diarrhoea, and can be toxic, especially in patients with liver or kidney problems.

 

Stop all medications and monitor (Option D): Stopping all medications without an alternative treatment plan is not appropriate in recurrent pericarditis cases. It can lead to persistent discomfort and potential complications.
